```
title: Added flag to ignore fluentd connect error on container start
body:
Added flag to ignore fluentd connect error during container start. The default is to fail the container start as with current log-drivers do.

Added also a flag to set the buffer limit for fluent client as that controls how much data the client will buffer while trying to reconnect.

Fixes #15757
Implements the flag as log-opt as requested in PR #17182

Signed-of-by: Jussi Nummelin jussi.nummelin@gmail.com

title: Docs: Docker guide engine/userguide/networkingcontainers/ - missing --format flag in example
body:
https://docs.docker.com/engine/userguide/networkingcontainers/ - one of the examples is missing --format (or -f) parameter. In the "Add containers to a network" section, after the words:
"Then, get the IP address of your web", there is an example:
```
$ docker inspect '{{range .NetworkSettings.Networks}}{{.IPAddress}}{{end}}' web
```
It should be, similar to the one above:
```
$ docker inspect --format='{{range .NetworkSettings.Networks}}{{.IPAddress}}{{end}}' web
```
otherwise the user gets an error:
```
$ docker inspect '{{range .NetworkSettings.Networks}}{{.IPAddress}}{{end}}' certsignd
Error: No such image or container: {{range .NetworkSettings.Networks}}{{.IPAddress}}{{end}}
```
and a very long JSON blob with the full config.
```

```
title: named data volume instead of data container
body:
(This is a **feature request**)

Perhaps this was discussed somewhere, but I couldn't find something with a quick search.

I was under the impression that the new volume subsystem in 1.9 would replace the need for data-only containers. There are a couple of issues with the data-only containers approach. Basically the need is for a persistent named set of data volumes which are initialised with the contents of respective dirs in the base image. However data-only containers add noise to both the list of containers and the list of images, and prevent me from assigning meaningful names to data volumes.

Consider these two scenarios:

1. I need a persistent volume for storing uploaded images or I want to deploy my app code/jars somewhere but still be able to re-tweak the container using it.
2. I need a persistent volume for my mysql's `/var/lib/mysql`.

Unless I missed something, in the first case I can:

1. Create a named data volume.
2. Mount it when creating a container using the notation <volume name>:<path inside container>

In this case:
 Applications Desktop Documents Downloads Google Drive Library Movies Music Pictures Public src `docker ps` will not show any redundant never-to-be-run containers.
 Applications Desktop Documents Downloads Google Drive Library Movies Music Pictures Public src `docker volume ls` will be easy to interpret - I gave a name to this particular volume when I created it.
 Applications Desktop Documents Downloads Google Drive Library Movies Music Pictures Public src `docker inspect` will easily show me that a container is using my named volume.
 Applications Desktop Documents Downloads Google Drive Library Movies Music Pictures Public src `docker images` will remain clean and not retain unnamed images after retagging.

However now consider scenario no. 2, all that has really changed is that when I create this volume, I want it initialised from `/var/lib/mysql` of a particular image. However I am forced to do the following:

1. Create a "data only container".
2. Use the `--volumes-from` option when creating the app container.

In this case:
 Applications Desktop Documents Downloads Google Drive Library Movies Music Pictures Public src `docker ps` shows x2 number of containers, and unless I choose a good naming scheme could end up very messy.
 Applications Desktop Documents Downloads Google Drive Library Movies Music Pictures Public src `docker volume ls` shows a bunch of random ids that tell me nothing about what's inside those volumes or where I've mounted them.
 Applications Desktop Documents Downloads Google Drive Library Movies Music Pictures Public src `docker inspect` again shows the random ids which are less helpful.
 Applications Desktop Documents Downloads Google Drive Library Movies Music Pictures Public src `docker images` will show unnamed images, since if I make changes to the base image, I can't easily re-create the data-only container to use the new image with the existing volumes. This container sticks around pointing to the old image.

----

There are a couple of ways I can think of that can help here:

1. Simplest option IMO - provide a `volume rename` verb. This isn't the ideal solution, but I can easily script the rest. However even if using a different solution, I think this operation should be available regardless.
2. Add some option to initialise a new volume from a declared volume of some image. The problem here is that an image can declare several volumes and they have no names, so will have to be referred to by path. Not as convenient as the `--volumes-from` switch.
3. Add or tweak existing options to `run` or `create` to give names to certain volumes when they are auto-created and initialised just as they are now. This will replace the need for `--volumes-from` and data-only containers altogether. For example:

 docker run -d --name us.mysql -v us.data:/var/lib/mysql mysql 
 docker run -d --name eu.mysql -v eu.data:/var/lib/mysql mysql 

 Will result in the creation of two data volumes named `us.data` and `eu.data` *and* their init from the contents of `/var/lib/mysql` of the `mysql` image *if* they don't exist, or mount the existing ones if they already exist.
4. Another option I thought of is declaring "data volume sets" or "groups". Which basically completely replace data-only containers. In this case the commands might look something like:

 docker volume create-set --name us.mysql.data mysql
 docker run -d --name us.mysql --volumes-from us.mysql.data mysql

 In this case the `--volumes-from` refers to the set of data volumes which are collectively named rather than individually named. The only problem here is that it creates possible clashes between volume names and container names, perhaps a solution to that is a new `--volume-set` option instead.
```

```
title: Dockerfile caching behavior for build-args is not documented
body:
The official dockerfile reference doesn't speak to how changing a build argument will affect the docker build cache.

http://docs.docker.com/engine/reference/builder/#arg

I did a little experiment and i believe the behavior is as follows:

1. If the argument changes then the cache is busted at the first usage of that argument (not at the argument declaration)
2. The cache remembers previous invocations (not just the last one). So switching a build arg from A to B to C to B to A (all else held equal) will force new layers for the first A, B and C and then will use the cache for the second B and A.
```

```
title: Update ubuntulinux.md
docker container filesystem became `read-only` after running 5 months
body:
BUG REPORT INFORMATION

Use the commands below to provide key information from your environment:

docker version

```
# docker version
Client version: 1.3.2
Client API version: 1.15
Go version (client): go1.2.2
Git commit (client): a43e801
OS/Arch (client): linux/amd64
Server version: 1.3.2
Server API version: 1.15
Go version (server): go1.2.2
Git commit (server): a43e801
```

docker info

```
# docker info
Containers: 1
Images: 76
Storage Driver: devicemapper
 Pool Name: docker-252:16-524291-pool
 Pool Blocksize: 65.54 kB
 Data file: /data/docker/devicemapper/devicemapper/data
 Metadata file: /data/docker/devicemapper/devicemapper/metadata
 Data Space Used: 7.292 GB
 Data Space Total: 107.4 GB
 Metadata Space Used: 6.828 MB
 Metadata Space Total: 2.147 GB
 Library Version: 1.02.89-RHEL6 (2014-09-01)
Execution Driver: native-0.2
Kernel Version: 2.6.32-431.el6.x86_64
Operating System: <unknown>
```

uname -a

```
# uname -a
Linux localhost 2.6.32-431.el6.x86_64 #1 SMP Fri Mar 14 11:51:38 CST 2014 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux
```

Provide additional environment details (AWS, VirtualBox, physical, etc.): KVM

List the steps to reproduce the issue:
1. start a container with below command

```
# docker run -d --name graphite --net=host -v /data/graphite/storage:/data/graphite/storage local-registry/chengweiv5/graphite:0.2-dev-2da77a3
```

2. wait for 5 months

Describe the results you received: the container `/` filesystem became Read-only

Describe the results you expected: the container `/' filesystem is still Read-write

Provide additional info you think is important:

I have a graphite container started 5 months ago and I suddenly it doesn't work anymore because the host data partition is full which I mounted to docker container.

From the graphite log, it says below:

~~~
Traceback (most recent call last):
 File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/django/core/handlers/base.py", line 101, in get_response
 request.path_info)
 File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/django/core/urlresolvers.py", line 252, in resolve
 sub_match = pattern.resolve(new_path)
 File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/django/core/urlresolvers.py", line 158, in resolve
 return ResolverMatch(self.callback, args, kwargs, self.name)
 File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/django/core/urlresolvers.py", line 164, in _get_callback
 self._callback = get_callable(self._callback_str)
 File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/django/utils/functional.py", line 124, in wrapper
 result = func(*args)
 File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/django/core/urlresolvers.py", line 91, in get_callable
 lookup_view = getattr(import_module(mod_name), func_name)
 File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/django/utils/importlib.py", line 35, in import_module
 __import__(name)
 File "/opt/graphite/webapp/graphite/browser/views.py", line 20, in <module>
 from graphite.util import getProfile, getProfileByUsername, defaultUser, json
 File "/opt/graphite/webapp/graphite/util.py", line 31, in <module>
 from graphite.logger import log
 File "/opt/graphite/webapp/graphite/logger.py", line 75, in <module>
 log = GraphiteLogger() # import-shared logger instance
 File "/opt/graphite/webapp/graphite/logger.py", line 40, in __init__
 self.infoHandler = Rotater(self.infoLogFile,when="midnight",backupCount=1)
 File "/usr/lib/python2.7/logging/handlers.py", line 171, in __init__
 BaseRotatingHandler.__init__(self, filename, 'a', encoding, delay)
 File "/usr/lib/python2.7/logging/handlers.py", line 64, in __init__
 logging.FileHandler.__init__(self, filename, mode, encoding, delay)
 File "/usr/lib/python2.7/logging/__init__.py", line 903, in __init__
 StreamHandler.__init__(self, self._open())
 File "/usr/lib/python2.7/logging/__init__.py", line 928, in _open
 stream = open(self.baseFilename, self.mode)
IOError: [Errno 30] Read-only file system: '/var/log/graphite/info.log'
~~~

it's quite interesting because I didn't mount any thing as RO to /var or its subdirectory.

So I'm trying to create a file in `/` of the container

```
# docker exec -it graphite /bin/touch /file
/bin/touch: cannot touch '/file': Read-only file system
```

below are more details.

```
# docker ps
CONTAINER ID IMAGE COMMAND CREATED STATUS PORTS NAMES
38a6d1080f40 local-registry/chengweiv5/graphite:0.2-dev-2da77a3 "/sbin/my_init" 5 months ago Up 5 months graphite 
```

I started this container with command

```
# docker run -d --name graphite --net=host -v /data/graphite/storage:/data/graphite/storage local-registry/chengweiv5/graphite:0.2-dev-2da77a3
```

It was works fine, but now has a `Read-only` root filesystem, weird!

----------END REPORT ---------

#ENEEDMOREINFO
```

title: Unable to cd into directory after chown
body:
I am just trying to copy some files in the container and ``chown`` them so that the non-root user can access them.

The problem is even though the permissions are set correctly, I am still unable to ``cd`` into the directory.

```
openchain@e1f19b15c9c1:/openchain.server/approot/src$ ls -al
total 28
drwx------ 17 openchain openchain 4096 Nov 16 10:02 .
drwx------ 5 openchain openchain 4096 Nov 16 10:02 ..
drwx------ 2 openchain openchain 4096 Nov 16 10:02 Openchain.Abstractions
drwx------ 5 openchain openchain 4096 Nov 16 10:02 Openchain.Ledger
drwx------ 2 openchain openchain 4096 Nov 16 10:02 Openchain.Ledger.Blockchain
drwx------ 14 openchain openchain 4096 Nov 16 10:02 Openchain.Server
drwx------ 2 openchain openchain 4096 Nov 16 10:02 Openchain.Sqlite
openchain@e1f19b15c9c1:/openchain.server/approot/src$ cd Openchain.Abstractions/
bash: cd: Openchain.Abstractions/: Permission denied
```

I am using Docker 1.9.0:

